newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Confident Hong Kong seen posing challenge to China.
newsitem.headline: Confident Hong Kong seen posing challenge to China.

text.p: If Hong Kong people fear China will strangle their freedom after the July 1 handover, they are showing remarkably little anxiety as the clock ticks closer.

With little more than three weeks to go before the extrovert community of 6.4 million people returns to Beijing's fold, more than 50,000 simply ignored future leader Tung Chee-hwa's exhortation to forget "the baggage of June 4".

Young and old, rich and poor, cradling flickering candles and crooning democracy anthems, they turned out on Wednesday to mourn those those killed when Chinese tanks crushed a nascent pro-democracy movement at Beijing's Tiananmen Square on June 4, 1989.

There was no repeat of the burnings in effigy of Chinese leaders, of defaced Communist flags or calls for the overthrow of "the butchers" of Beijing which propelled more than one million horrified people to the streets eight years earlier.
The protests were peaceful, even benign.

Political scientist Michael Yahuda of the London School of Economics has written that China's emergence as a world player will be judged by how it handles Hong Kong -- hugely successful under British rule -- when it takes over at midnight on June 30.

The fact that so many Hong Kong people casually dismissed the hint to stay home demonstrates that China has a challenge on its hands in absorbing such a brash, self-confident community into the motherland.
Hong Kong, just 23 days before the British leave, has had 13 years since Britain agreed to return its colony to scrutinise the "what-ifs ?" of the handover from every conceivable angle.
The pessimists have decamped in a tide of "yacht people". Between quarter-to-half a million of them left primarily for Canada and Australia -- many in the aftermath of Tiananmen.
The cautious have furnished their boltholes and judiciously spread their funds in a variety of markets.
With their bets hedged, a philosophical but generally positive mood of wait and see has spread in the British colony.

"Hong Kong people are generally satisfed with their lives, they approve of the way they are governed," says Michael DeGolyer, director of a long-term study into the transition based at Hong Kong's Baptist University.

The message from Hong Kong is that China should demonstrate it will be business as usual, to carry out promises contained in the 1984 Sino-British treaty on the handover to leave capitalist Hong Kong alone to run itself.
It would appear that the message to handle Hong Kong with kid gloves has been received loud and clear in the senior ranks of China's People's Liberation Army (PLA).
"Tiananmen is the hurdle the PLA has got to jump," the last Commander of British Forces Major-General Bryan Dutton observed on Thursday, the day after the Tiananmen vigil in Hong Kong.
Dutton said the incoming commanders were well aware they had to demonstrate such incidents lay in the past.

He reserved judgement on how events would unfold -- "the PLA must answer for themselves" -- but gave credit to the diplomacy and professionalism of the advance guard, the cream of the crop, sent in recent weeks to prepare for the PLA garrison.

In smart new uniforms designed for the occasion, unarmed in accordance with London's wishes, their arrival led by Major-General Zhou Borong, China's only graduate of Britain's Royal College of Defence Studies, was low-key and unthreatening.

"Even in 1988 he (Zhou) appeared to be the perfect choice for a senior officer in such a sensitive appointment as Hong Kong after its handover to China," Major-General John Evans, one of Zhou's former tutors, told Reuters recently.
